item.title: Broken Links
item.description: I recently made a local backup of this site and in the process discovered a bunch of broken links which I list in this thread.

item.title: Increasing amount of 502 (Bad Gateway) Errors
item.description: An increasing amount of pages have been giving 502 errors over these past few days - is there a known cause?
item.content:encoded:
Hi!

I've been using this website for a while now, and as of recent I've noticed a lot of 502 errors. I saw one mentioned already with Fire Genasi, but it's covered a lot of different pages - spell:summon-aberration, spells:wizard, etc. Many spells and other options seem to frequently return these errors, some lasting for several days at a time.

From what I know about these, it's possible that they can be from my end instead of the server's - I have been able to access some of those pages while in Incognito mode. But, since I'm not the only one, I was curious about what others have found and think is happening.

item.title: New actual play - Level Quest - starts Nov 9th
item.description:
Our table is streaming our next D&D campaign. It will be aired live at https://www.twitch.tv/levelquest on Wednesdays at 7pm PT beginning Nov. 9th.
Come join us for some gritty, elemental, chaotic fun!
item.content:encoded:
Hi y'all,

I’m Kory, the DM for a new D&D actual play stream called Level Quest airing Wednesdays at 7:00 pm PT on Twitch. Real people, remote play, melodrama, inappropriate comedy… the usual.
Session #1 is scheduled for Nov. 9th Nov. 23rd – we’d be honored to have you check out our story.

THE SETTING - ILLISTERA
Level Quest takes place in the world of Illistera (ILL-is-TARE-uh) – an unforgiving and elemental land yet ravaged by echoes of the past the brightest minds are still trying to understand. Civilization struggles forward despite raging storms and violent neighbors. Hungering monstrosities await the foolhardy braving the wilds in search of glory and long-buried treasures.

THE CAMPAIGN - SOULBOUND
The PCs are regular folk. Commoners thrust into a story larger than they could have imagined, beset by visions of the past, and bestowed with power beyond the reach of most. What they choose to do with it… well, that’s what we’re here to find out.

The land is as threatening as its denizens, meaning survival is far from guaranteed for our heroes. They do, however, have one advantage…

If death simply meant a new beginning, how would you approach life? Would you sacrifice yourself for a cause knowing all it costs is time? We explore these questions and more as the PCs are born again and again, reckoning with the long-term consequences of their actions in a manner unseen in most campaigns.

The decisions will be difficult.
The challenges brutal.
Welcome to Illistera.

*

If you want to see some clips or the full vid of our “tech run part 2” from last night (11/2) find us on Twitch. Nothing shown there is canon :P

Thanks for reading! I hope this intrigues you enough to toss us a follow and stop by our inaugural stream on Wednesday, Nov 9th Nov. 23rd. We’ll also be posting VODs to Youtube and creating a podcast version for on-the-go enjoyment.

If you would like more information or to learn a bit about our party, check out our website. I’m happy to answer questions here as well.

Your Unseen Servant,
Kory

item.title: "DnDOne"
item.content:encoded:
Opening up a thread to start discussion and have a place to share thoughts about the new information regarding "the next evolution of dnd" and what it means for the overall shape of the wikidot.

From what I can feel, despite the marketing, is that it is intended to be a 5.5e.

My current thoughts on the matter are that, depending on how it turns out on release, we could do with a sister website? I.e., theres the Dnd5e.wikidot, and then the DnD5.5e or DnD1 or DnD[whatever] wikidot, which both would include a link and text on the frontpage along the lines of "This content is for the DnD5e/5.5e edition of the game, content from Dnd5.5e/5e can be found on our sister wiki, [Link]", reason being from the UA article is that while the content does feel compatible-ish, it might cause massive amounts of bloat for the website if a lot of PHB stuff is doubled, or sections are doubled, or whatnot. And I'd prefer to avoid bloat and unwieldyness, since what I think makes the 5ewikidot a good website is its comfortable and easy to access formatting.

Yeah, thoughts from everyone else?

(edit: thinking about feats from another post actually, the sister sites feats section might end up a whole lot cleaner if thats what we do, since feats will be organized by level, so we could probably do for them a page similiar to what we do for spells (: )

item.title: Warlock Invocation page layout
item.content:encoded:
Hey just wanted to double check what we were doing with the warlock page and start a discussion, since I feel its worth discussing how to handle the UA in it?

So recap to bring everyone up to speed, the UA work I was doing previously (I'll get back to double checking it all, sorry, had assignments due in the recent weeks) had us find a bunch of UA invocations that never made it to print, and also a bunch were revised or reworked. Though, for archival purposes I took this as a chance to move all the UA warlock feats into a seperate subpage (linked on the original invocations page), as so that the invocation page only holds printed content, and then if a person wanted to view old UA, they could hop into the subpage. However, a few days back, this was reverted, and the new UA invocations moved onto the main invocation page?

I think since there is uncertainty in what we want to do, I feel bringing it up in a discussion thread is a good idea, so thats what this is. Would we rather all the UA invocations sit on the main invocations page as they did before, or would we rather to have them all on a separate sub page in order to organize them seperately and make it more clear between which is which.

Yeah

item.title: UA-work
item.content:encoded:
Im mostly using this thread as a way to track progress as I go through each UA to ensure we have its contents up on the wikidot (thank you very much cotteneyenoh for the checklist <333 http://dnd5e.wikidot.com/forum/t-14715608/errata-checklist), since yeah, I find having a discussion forum helps with me tracking my work.

First up out of order is UA warlock and wizard's Eldritch Invocations, which we dont have, despite having the ravenqueen warlock from said UA.

item.title: DMG Races
item.content:encoded:
With the work towards finalizing and front-page-ifying the new lineages pages, I got thinking towards something I loosely remembered, and, today had found it:

The DMG has in it, a bunch of additional, non standard races. These include things such as gnolls, zombies, skeletons and grimlocks.

So, I'm wondering what peoples thoughts are towards them, and whether they should be added.

On one opinion, they are listed as NPC races, and the book in discussing them describes them as intended to be used for DM's making NPC's (Some of the races on that same list already had player races, but the NPC race version of them exists as a simplified form of them). So, odds are these weren't really made with players in mind (and well, items such as the skeleton have stats such as +1+2-6-4-4 in their arrays)

On the other hand, the Oathbreaker Paladin and the Death Cleric are also DMG subclasses, and they are listed on the wikidot.

But then, against that argument, is the fact the DMG does go out of its way to discuss these races as player options

So yeah, I wanted to hear other people heres thoughts on it. Personally, on one hand, they are race options in an official WoTC book, but on the other, they most definitely do not feel like they are designed for players (as can tell with things like abilities that are +1 to hit all attacks, which work for NPCs, but not players), and they are also sorta hidden in the book.

If we did add them, I feel we'd need to go out of our way somewhere to point out that they would be very, very non standard, (probably more so than the homebrew we list on the wikidot even), since I feel theyd need a bit of context to explain them, and I wouldn't want to have a new player who uses the site use them without said knowledge

Plus, it does feel aimed at DMs, so it might not match the wikidots usual "player focused" attitude.

Yeah, that about sums it up for me. Just wanted to bring them up for the sake of discussion and so as that we were all aware of them if we were not already

Oh, if you want to take a look at the races yourself, they're on the table on page 282 of the DMG

item.title: Distinguishing non Standard content
item.description: Should the wikidot make better effort to distinguish between content from standard sources and setting specific sources
item.content:encoded:
With the release of Strixhaven meaning we will be adding the content from the book to the website, it's had me thinking about the way this website presents content from non-standard settings (partially due to the concerns for balance with some of said content within the book)

the current form of the website doesn't do too much really, aside from seperating some stuff on the frontpage, such as 'setting specific races', however with the fact that many people use this website to learn more about the game, I feel the website should take better effort to distinguish between core and non-standard content. Especially since, with the release of Strixhaven, the dev's are basically announcing their intent to have different settings have different amounts of player balance. (Strixhaven backgrounds give a free feat. And for older examples, the Ravnica backgrounds added extra spells to your class spell list)

[Content] is part of the [setting] setting, and may not be designed for play outside of its original setting. Check with your DM whether it is good to use if you are going to be using it in play

or something along those lines, just to denote that the content is not usually part of the 'base game'. I mean, I feel like we have a sorta responsibility to try to make the game easier on others, especially others who are getting into the game, since we do run a website like this, and making stuff clear that its not part of the normal should be something we should do.

Yeah the sources exist, but if you're a new player, something saying 'Source: Unearthed Arcana 1', 'Source: Xanathar's Guide to Everything' or 'Source: Strixhaven: Curriculum of Chaos' is kinda meaningless, if they even do read them
